member.name: T:OpenNETCF.IO.DriveInfo
member.summary: Provides access to information on a drive.
member.remarks: This class models a drive and provides methods and properties to query for drive information. Use to determine what drives are available, and the capacity and available free space on the drive.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.IO.DriveInfo.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Provides access to information on the specified drive.
member.remarks: Use this class to obtain information on drives. The drive name must be a valid Windows CE volume path e.g. "\Storage Card". You cannot use this method to obtain information on drive names that are a null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic) or use UNC (\\server\share) paths.
member.exception: The drive name cannot be a null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic).

member.summary: Creates a new file. If the file exists, the function overwrites the file and clears the existing attributes.

member.summary: Opens the file. The function fails if the file does not exist.

member.summary: Opens the file. Once opened, the file is truncated so that its size is zero bytes. The calling process must open the file with at least Write access.

member.summary: Provides data for the directory events: , , .

The FileSystemEventArgs class is passed as a parameter to event handlers for these events:
The event occurs when changes are made to the size, system attributes, last write time, last access time, or security permissions in a file or directory in the specified of a .
The event occurs when a file or directory in the specified of a is created.
The event occurs when a file or directory in the specified of a is deleted. For more information, see .

member.name: T:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.DebugMessage
member.summary: Use the static methods of this class to output data to a device's debug port. Messages will be sent only in Debug builds, allowing developers to easily compile out messaging.
member.remarks: This is the equivalent of the unmanaged DEBUGMSG macro and applies only to generic CE devices. Most commercial Pocket PC and SmartPhone devices do not expose a debug port.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.DebugMessage.Write(System.Boolean,System.String)
member.summary: If condition evaluates to true and the current assembly is a Debug build, message will be output on the device's debug port.
member.param: When true output will be sent to the debug port
Text to output

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.DebugMessage.Write(System.Boolean,System.Object)
member.summary: If condition evaluates to true and the current assembly is a Debug build, the result from obj.ToString will be output on the device's debug port.
member.param: When true output will be sent to the debug port
Object to call ToString() on

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.DebugMessage.WriteLine(System.Boolean,System.String)
member.summary: If condition evaluates to true and the current assembly is a Debug build, message will be output on the device's debug port followed by a carriage return and new line. Lines output with WriteLine are also affected by calls to Indent or Unindent.
member.param: When true output will be sent to the debug port
Text to output

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.DebugMessage.Indent
member.summary: Increases the indent level used by WriteLine by two spaces

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.DebugMessage.Unindent
member.summary: Decreases the indent level used by WriteLine by two spaces

member.name: T:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.EventLog
member.summary: Class is similar to the System.Diagnostics.EventLog in the full framework with a few differences. 1. Since CE.Net and PPC have no event log we write the log to the application root directory as an XML file 2. Every Application will have it's own log. There will not be one log system/device wide 3. Attempted to keep as close as possible to the full framework class but some things are missing

member.remarks: Getting this property creates an array that holds a copy of the entry's event-specific binary data. Event-specific data is sometimes used to store information that the application will process independently of the Event Viewer, for example, to make reports from the log file.

member.summary: Gets the application-specific event identifier of this event entry.

member.summary: Gets the index of this entry in the event log.

member.remarks: This number is not necessarily zero based.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.EventLogEntry.MachineName
member.summary: Gets the name of the computer on which this entry was generated.
member.value: The name of the computer that contains the event log.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.EventLogEntry.Message
member.summary: Gets the localized message associated with this event entry.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.EventLogEntry.Source
member.summary: Gets the name of the application that generated this event.
member.remarks: The event source indicates what logged the event. It is often the name of the application, or the name of a subcomponent of the application if the application is large. Applications and services usually write to (and therefore are sources for) the Application log or a custom log. Device drivers usually write to the System log.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.EventLogEntry.TimeGenerated
member.summary: Gets the local time at which this event was generated.
member.value: A DateTime that represents the local time at which this event was generated.
member.remarks: This member holds the time that an event was generated. This might not be the same as the time when the event information was written to the event log. For the latter, read the TimeWritten property.Theres almost always going to be a lag between the time something happens and the time it is logged, if only milliseconds. Usually, it is more important to know when the event was generated, unless you want to see if there is a significant lag in logging. That can happen if your log files are on a different server and you are experiencing a bottleneck.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.EventLogEntry.TimeWritten
member.summary: Gets the local time at which this event was written to the log.
member.value: A DateTime that represents the local time at which this event was written to the log.
member.remarks: This member holds the time that an event's information is written to the event log. This might not be the same time as when the event was generated. For the latter, read the TimeGenerated property.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.FileVersionInfo.FileMajorPart
member.summary: Gets the major part of the version number.
member.value: A value representing the major part of the version number.
member.remarks:
Typically, a version number is displayed as "major number.minor number.build number.private part number". A file version number is a 64-bit number that holds the version number for a file as follows:
The first 16 bits are the number.
The next 16 bits are the number.
The third set of 16 bits are the number.
The last 16 bits are the number. This property gets the first set of 16 bits.

member.name: T:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.Logging
member.summary: This class enables you to turn on and off the creation of log files with diagnostic information about interoperability, loading the application, and networking

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.Logging.IncludeAppNameInLogFileName
member.summary: If there are two applications writing log files to the same directory, the older log file will always get overwritten with the newer log file when the second application is run. This key can be used as a differentiator for the log files.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.Logging.IncludeProcessIDInLogFileName
member.summary: This key is useful if you want to run the same application but have separate logs. This adds the process ID to the log file name, so that each run of the same application creates a new log file with a different name.

member.name: T:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.ProcessHelper
member.summary: Provides helper methods for processes.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.ProcessHelper.GetCurrentProcessID
member.summary: This function returns the process identifier of the calling process.
member.returns: The return value is the process identifier of the calling process.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.ProcessHelper.GetCurrentProcessHandle
member.summary: Gets a new component and associates it with the currently active process.
member.returns: A new component associated with the process resource that is running the calling application.
member.remarks: Use this method to create a new Process instance and associate it with the process resource on the local computer.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.ProcessHelper.GetCurrentThreadID
member.summary: This function returns the thread identifier, which is used as a handle of the calling thread.
member.returns: The thread identifier of the calling thread indicates success.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.ProcessHelper.GetCurrentThreadHandle
member.summary: This function returns a pseudohandle for the current thread.
member.returns: The return value is a pseudohandle for the current thread.

remarks.p: A pseudohandle is a special constant that is interpreted as the current thread handle.
The calling thread can use this handle to specify itself whenever a thread handle is required.This handle has the maximum possible access to the thread object.

The function cannot be used by one thread to create a handle that can be used by other threads to refer to the first thread. The handle is always interpreted as referring to the thread that is using it.
The pseudohandle need not be closed when it is no longer needed. Calling the CloseHandle function with this handle has no effect.

member.remarks: This is the equivalent of the unmanaged RETAILMSG macro and applies only to generic CE devices. Most commercial Pocket PC and SmartPhone devices do not expose a debug port.

member.name: T:OpenNETCF.Enum2
member.summary: Provides helper functions for Enumerations.
member.remarks: Extends the System.Enum Class.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Enum2.GetName(System.Type,System.Object)
member.summary: Retrieves the name of the constant in the specified enumeration that has the specified value.
member.param: An enumeration type.
The value of a particular enumerated constant in terms of its underlying type.
member.returns: A string containing the name of the enumerated constant in enumType whose value is value, or null if no such constant is found.
member.exception: enumType is not an System.Enum. -or- value is neither of type enumType nor does it have the same underlying type as enumType.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Enum2.GetNames(System.Type)
member.summary: Retrieves an array of the names of the constants in a specified enumeration.
member.param: An enumeration type.
member.returns: A string array of the names of the constants in enumType. The elements of the array are sorted by the values of the enumerated constants.
member.exception: enumType parameter is not an System.Enum
member.example: The follow example shows how to enumerate the members of the System.DayOfWeek enumeration by adding them to a ComboBox:- [Visual Basic] Dim thisDOW As New DayOfWeek For Each thisDOW In OpenNETCF.Enum.GetValues(Type.GetType("System.DayOfWeek")) ComboBox1.Items.Add(thisDOW) Next [C#] foreach(DayOfWeek thisdow in OpenNETCF.Enum.GetValues(typeof(DayOfWeek))) { comboBox1.Items.Add(thisdow); }

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Enum2.GetUnderlyingType(System.Type)
member.summary: Returns the underlying type of the specified enumeration.>
member.param: An enumeration type.
member.returns: The underlying of enumType.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Enum2.GetValues(System.Type)
member.summary: Retrieves an array of the values of the constants in a specified enumeration.
member.param: An enumeration type.
member.returns: An System.Array of the values of the constants in enumType. The elements of the array are sorted by the values of the enumeration constants.
member.exception: enumType parameter is not an System.Enum

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Enum2.IsDefined(System.Type,System.Object)
member.summary: Returns an indication whether a constant with a specified value exists in a specified enumeration.
member.param: An enumeration type.
The value or name of a constant in enumType.
member.returns: true if a constant in enumType has a value equal to value; otherwise, false.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Enum2.Parse(System.Type,System.String)
member.summary: Converts the string representation of the name or numeric value of one or more enumerated constants to an equivalent enumerated object.
member.param: The of the enumeration.
A string containing the name or value to convert.
member.returns: An object of type enumType whose value is represented by value.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Enum2.Parse(System.Type,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Converts the string representation of the name or numeric value of one or more enumerated constants to an equivalent enumerated object. A parameter specifies whether the operation is case-sensitive.
member.param: The of the enumeration.
A string containing the name or value to convert.
If true, ignore case; otherwise, regard case.
member.returns: An object of type enumType whose value is represented by value.
member.exception: enumType is not an . -or- value is either an empty string ("") or only contains white space. -or- value is a name, but not one of the named constants defined for the enumeration.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Enum2.ToObject(System.Type,System.Object)
member.summary: Returns an instance of the specified enumeration set to the specified value.
member.param: An enumeration.
The value.
member.returns: An enumeration object whose value is value.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Enum2.Format(System.Type,System.Object,System.String)
member.summary: Converts the specified value of a specified enumerated type to its equivalent string representation according to the specified format.
member.remarks: The valid format values are: "G" or "g" - If value is equal to a named enumerated constant, the name of that constant is returned; otherwise, the decimal equivalent of value is returned. For example, suppose the only enumerated constant is named, Red, and its value is 1. If value is specified as 1, then this format returns "Red". However, if value is specified as 2, this format returns "2". "X" or "x" - Represents value in hexadecimal without a leading "0x". "D" or "d" - Represents value in decimal form. "F" or "f" - Behaves identically to "G" or "g", except the FlagsAttribute is not required to be present on the Enum declaration. "V" or "v" - If value is equal to a named enumerated constant, the value of that constant is returned; otherwise, the decimal equivalent of value is returned.
member.param: The enumeration type of the value to convert.
The value to convert.
The output format to use.
member.returns: A string representation of value.

member.name: T:OpenNETCF.Media.SoundPlayer
member.summary: Controls playback of a sound from a .wav file.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class, attaches the .wav file within the specified .

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Media.SoundPlayer.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class and attaches the specified .wav file.
member.param: The location of a .wav file to load.
member.remarks: The string passed to the soundLocation parameter must be a path to a .wav file. If the path is invalid, the object will still be constructed, but subsequent calls to a load or play method will fail.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Media.SoundPlayer.Play
member.summary: Plays the .wav file using a new thread.
member.remarks: The Play method plays the sound using a new thread. If the .wav file has not been specified or it fails to load, the Play method will play the default beep sound.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Media.SoundPlayer.PlaySync
member.summary: Plays the .wav file using the UI thread.
member.remarks: The PlaySync method uses the current thread to play a .wav file, preventing the thread from handling other messages until the load is complete. After a .wav file is successfully loaded from a Stream or URL path, future calls to playback methods for the SoundPlayer object will not need to reload the .wav file until the path for the sound changes. If the .wav file has not been specified or it fails to load, the PlaySync method will play the default beep sound.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Media.SoundPlayer.PlayLooping
member.summary: Plays and loops the .wav file using a new thread and loads the .wav file first if it has not been loaded.
member.remarks: The PlayLooping method plays and loops the sound using a new thread. If the .wav file has not been specified or it fails to load, the PlayLooping method will play the default beep sound.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Media.SoundPlayer.Stop
member.summary: Stops playback of the sound if playback is occurring.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Threading.EventWaitHandle.Pulse
member.summary: Provides a single operation that sets to signaled the state of the specified event object and then resets it to nonsignaled after releasing the appropriate number of waiting threads.
member.remarks: For a manual-reset event object, all waiting threads that can be released immediately are released. The function then resets the event object's state to nonsignaled and returns. For an auto-reset event object, the function resets the state to nonsignaled and returns after releasing a single waiting thread, even if multiple threads are waiting. If no threads are waiting, or if no thread can be released immediately, PulseEvent simply sets the event object's state to nonsignaled and returns. For a thread using the multiple-object wait functions to wait for all specified objects to be signaled, PulseEvent can set the event object's state to signaled and reset it to nonsignaled without causing the wait function to return. This happens if not all of the specified objects are simultaneously signaled.
member.returns: true on success, otherwise false

member.name: T:OpenNETCF.Threading.SemaphoreFullException
member.summary: The exception that is thrown when the method is called on a semaphore whose count is already at the maximum.
member.remarks: The count on a semaphore is decremented each time a thread enters the semaphore, and incremented when a thread releases the semaphore. When the count is zero, subsequent requests block until other threads release the semaphore. When all threads have released the semaphore, the count is at the maximum value specified when the semaphore was created. If a programming error causes a thread to call the method at this point, a is thrown.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Timers.Timer2.Start
member.summary: Starts raising the Elapsed event by setting Enabled to true
member.remarks: If Enabled is set to true and AutoReset is set to false, the Timer raises the Elapsed event only once, the first time he interval elapses. When Enabled is true and AutoReset is true, the Timer continues to raise the Elapsed event on the specified interval. You can also start timing by setting Enabled to true. NoteIf AutoReset is false, the Start method must be called in order to start the count again.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Timers.Timer2.Stop
member.summary: Stops raising the Elapsed event by setting Enabled to false.

member.remarks: if this is set, the TimerCallback must be overridden

member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the Timer should raise the Elapsed event each time the specified interval elapses or only after the first time it elapses

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Timers.Timer2.Enabled
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the Timer should raise the Elapsed event.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Timers.Timer2.Interval
member.summary: Gets or sets the interval at which to either raise the Elapsed event or run the TimerCallback method
member.remarks: Default Interval is 100ms

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Timers.Timer2.Resolution
member.summary: Resolution of the timer event, in milliseconds. The resolution increases with smaller values; a resolution of zero indicates periodic events should occur with the greatest possible accuracy. To reduce system overhead, however, you should use the maximum value appropriate for your application
member.remarks: Default value = 10ms

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Timers.Timer2.SynchronizingObject
member.summary: Gets or sets the object used to marshal event-handler calls that are issued when an interval has elapsed
member.remarks: When SynchronizingObject is a null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic), the method that handles the Elapsed event is called on a thread from the system-thread pool. For more information on system-thread pools, see ThreadPool. When the Elapsed event is handled by a visual Windows Forms component, such as a button, accessing the component through the system-thread pool might result in an exception or just might not work. Avoid this effect by setting SynchronizingObject to a Windows Forms component, which causes the method that handles the Elapsed event to be called on the same thread that the component was created on. If the Timer is used inside Visual Studio in a Windows Forms designer, SynchronizingObject is automatically set to the control that contains the Timer. For example, if you place a Timer on a designer for Form1 (which inherits from Form), the SynchronizingObject property of Timer is set to the instance of Form1.

member.summary: The owner of the monitor, or null if it's not owned by any thread.

member.summary: Number of levels of locking (0 for an unowned monitor, 1 after a single call to Enter, etc).

member.summary: Object to be used as a monitor for state changing.

member.summary: AutoResetEvent used to implement Wait/Pulse/PulseAll. Initially not signalled, so that a call to Wait will block until the first pulse.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Threading.Monitor2.waitCounter
member.summary: Number of threads waiting on this monitor.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Threading.Monitor2.enterExitEvent
member.summary: Event used for Enter/Exit. Initially signalled to allow the first thread to come in.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Threading.Monitor2.#ctor
member.summary: Creates a new monitor, not owned by any thread.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Threading.Monitor2.Enter
member.summary: Enters the monitor (locks it), blocking until the lock is held. If the monitor is already held by the current thread, its lock count is incremented.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Threading.Monitor2.TryEnter
member.summary: Attempts to enter the monitor (locking it) but does not block if the monitor is already owned.
member.returns: Whether or not the current thread now owns the monitor.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Threading.Monitor2.Exit
member.summary: Releases a level of locking, unlocking the monitor itself if the lock count becomes 0.
member.exception: If the current thread does not own the monitor.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Threading.Monitor2.Pulse
member.summary: Pulses the monitor once - a single waiting thread will be released and continue its execution after the current thread has exited the monitor. Unlike Pulse on the normal framework, no guarantee is made about which thread is woken.
member.exception: If the current thread does not own the monitor.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Threading.Monitor2.PulseAll
member.summary: Pulses the monitor such that all waiting threads are woken up. All threads will then try to regain the lock on this monitor. No order for regaining the lock is specified.
member.exception: If the current thread does not own the monitor.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Threading.Monitor2.Wait
member.summary: Relinquishes the lock on this monitor (whatever the lock count is) and waits for the monitor to be pulsed. After the monitor has been pulsed, the thread blocks again until it has regained the lock (at which point it will have the same lock count as it had before), and then the method returns.

member.summary: Exception thrown by when threading rules are violated (usually due to an operation being invoked on a monitor not owned by the current thread).
